data.title: Chirac reappoints Jean-Pierre Raffarin
data.meta_description: As expected after his overwhelming victory in the general elections, French interim Prime Minister Raffarin has been reappointed to lead the next centre-right government.
data.text:
The "Raffarin II" government will count 38 members (12 more than the interim government which took over from the socialist cabinet of Mr. Jospin after the Presidential elections). Most ministers of the interim cabinet are reconfirmed, except for the Minister for European affairs, Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres, who is under investigation for his alleged involvement in a party funding scandal.

One of the most remarkable appointments is the one of the former European Parliament President, Nicole Fontaine, as Minister for Industry. The post of European affairs minister goes to Mrs. Noelle Lenoir. Mrs. Lenoir is a lawyer with specialisation in bioethics and former member of the French constitutional Council (for more on her profile, see

Yahoo/AFP France)

Some other important cabinet members are:

Interior: Nicolas Sarkozy

Foreign affairs: Dominique Galouzeau de Villepin

Defence: Michele Alliot-Marie

Economy and Finance: Francis Mer

Social affairs: François Fillon

Ecology and Sustainable Development: Roselyne Bachelot-Narquin

Agriculture: Hervé Gaymard

Mr. Raffarin, who is a former member of the European Parliament (from 1989-95), wants to reduce taxes, combat crime and introduce reforms of France's health and pension systems. One of the priorities of the new government will be to improve the competitiveness of French companies, and the attractiveness of France for investors. According to some political experts, the Raffarin II government could become a more difficult partner for the European Union (esp. concerning France's budget austerity and reform of the Common Agricultural Policy).
